description: On March 17th, the government of Mali announced that schools will be closed for 3 weeks, starting on March 19th. On April 8th, the closure has been extended until May 9th. UPDATE: The original closure of school was set to last for three weeks until April 9, it has been extended on April 8 by the government to May 9 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description: On March 17th, the government of Mali announced that schools will be closed for 3 weeks, starting on March 19th. UPDATE: In Mali, schools - originally closed from March 19 - reopened on June 2 for university students and final year students who face final exams. The partial resumption of classes was boycotted by public sector teachers over fears of inadequate protection against Covid-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description:
On March 25th, in a televised address, President Keita 'announced the implementation of a nationwide curfew between 21:00 and 05:00 (local time) as of Friday, March 27, that will remain in place until further notice'. The national police is responsible for controlling the compliance with the curfew. 
 UPDATE: Prime Minister Boubou Cisse lifted the nationwide curfew, initially implemented to limit the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), as of May 9, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "Mali will indefinitely suspend flights from countries affected by coronavirus in a bid to control a possible outbreak of the pandemic there, the government said Tuesday. Exception from the suspension that begins Thursday will be given to cargo flights."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Mali is enforcing health monitoring on comers to Mali. it imposed a coronavirus disease surveillance form on entry points in the country for all those who enter Mali to fill in to be able to track virus circulation and any suspicious health symptoms which could be covid19 related.  it takes effect on June 18 2021, and has no specific end date up until the day this policy is being coded.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 12, 2020, it was announced that all travelers arriving in Mali will be subject to individual and collective hygiene measures at the entry gates (air and land).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Mali, the national parliamentary elections on March 29 2020 (1st round) were maintained, a day after the country's first coronavirus death. The second round was hold on April 19, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: A government´s decision to maintain certain events such as elections despite the risk of spreading the Corona virus

description: April 10, 2020 "Malian President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita has announced a coronavirus aid package [worth some 500 billion CFA francs (USD 832 million)] for poor people and hard-hit firms, as cases continue to rise in the war-torn West African state. [...] the government would shoulder water and electricity bills for the poorest people in April and May, among other measures. [...] The government would also distribute 56,000 tonnes of grain in food aid and 16,000 tonnes of animal feed, he added, and allow tax rebates for firms hit hard by the virus.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: A political measure providing financial aid, distributing food etc. to population groups
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Since 7 July and for a period of two months, the Civil Affairs Division of MINUSMA has been implementing a "Citizen Mobilization for Zero Coronavirus in Mali" project, in collaboration with Junior Chamber International (JCI) and the Coalition of Alternative Debts of Mali (CAD-MALI). This project, which concerns Bamako and several regions of Mali, aims to support the fight against coronavirus by involving civil society actors.

Through its important communication component, nearly five million people will be indirectly reached by the awareness messages, thanks in particular to community radio stations, public notices in six languages, loudspeakers in public places, social networks and through the distribution of handwashing kits.

In addition to the six communes of the District of Bamako, activities have already taken place in Mopti, Bandiagara, Djenné, Ségou and Gao. They will continue until the end of August in Timbuktu, Kidal, Ménaka, Taoudéni, Douentza and Tessalit.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)
